conclusion: Liquid will flow out from A, B, C, and D and needs to be predicted which container (E, F, or G) it will flow into after passing through baffles.
The image shows four inlets (A, B, C, D) at the top, each aligned with angled baffles that guide liquid flow. At the bottom, there are three exit compartments (E, F, G).
The baffles are angled differently, with some guiding liquid leftward and others rightward.
Each colour-coded inlet (A–D) is aligned with a set of angled baffles that guide the liquid left or right until it reaches the openings of the three exit compartments (E, F, G).
By following the deflections from top to bottom, the brown-coloured path (A) steers leftmost.
The pink-coloured path (B) remains near the centre.
The two blue-coloured paths (C, D) are guided rightward.
The brown-coloured path (A) ends up in container E.
The pink-coloured path (B) ends up in container F.
The blue-coloured paths (C, D) both end up in container G.
Final mapping: A → E, B → F, C → G, D → G.
